inscribed: Signed and dated in plate, lower left margin: Rembrandt f. 1639
catalograisonne: Bartsch 281; Biörklund and Barnard 39; Hind 167; Hollstein 132; Münz 259; New Hollstein 36.172

makers.displaydate: 1606–1669; born Leiden, Netherlands; died Amsterdam, Netherlands
makers.displaymaker: Rembrandt van Rijn, 1606–1669; born Leiden, Netherlands; died Amsterdam, Netherlands

texts.textentryhtml: While most of Rembrandt’s portrait etchings are of himself or his family, he also represented a wide range of Dutch citizens, including doctors, poets, businessmen, and government officials, typically in minimally defined interiors. This unusually detailed example depicts Jan Uytenbogaert, the recently appointed receiver-general (or tax collector) for Holland, the wealthiest province of the Dutch Republic. Probably made to celebrate Uytenbogaert’s promotion, this etching shows the thirty-one-year-old working in his office, seated at a carpet-covered table topped with scales and bags of gold as he records payments in a ledger. His art-collecting interests are reflected in the framed picture on the wall, while the interior also reveals a source of his material wealth: the tax-bearing elderly couple waiting in the doorway.
